critical_issues: All output files are empty JSON objects (`{}`) and fail the required schemas (as shown by validation errors for missing required fields). This makes them not practically usable for downstream review, despite not fabricating claims.

Severe coverage failure: none of the report’s main elements are captured, including the core question/context (L10-L12), study design and arms (L13-L17), cohorts and sizes (L18-L24), quantitative findings (L25-L34), controls/null results (L35-L40), mechanistic chain (L41-L47), and caveats/limitations (L48-L56).

Quantitative findings are entirely omitted: key numbers like immunopeptidome fractions (62.3% vs 37.3%, L28), MHC-I peptidome fractions (40.6% vs 20.6%, L29), p=0.01 survival comparison (L30), IFN score (3.1 vs 1.0, L31), PD-L1 fold-change (2.4x, L32), and CD8 density (1.8x, L33) are not reported.

Controls and conditional results are omitted: vaccine-only lack of durable control (L36), ICI-only limited activity (L37), lipid particle controls (L38), and IFNAR1 blockade eliminating benefit (L39) are not included, removing critical interpretation safeguards.

Caveats/limitations are omitted: the human analysis being retrospective/non-randomized with confounding (L49), timing variability (L50), heterogeneity (L51), mouse-to-human generalization limits (L52), and model-specificity of mechanistic readouts (L53) are not included, risking overconfidence if any summary were inferred.
No coherent public summary or claim audit can be performed because the outputs contain no content; this violates the usefulness and coherence criteria even though it avoids hallucination.

critical_issues: Missing a core study conclusion: the report’s main efficacy takeaway is that the combined intervention improves tumor control in mice (L46), but none of the JSON artifacts clearly capture this as a main finding/claim (it is only vaguely implied in narrative phrasing like “more sensitive” without explicitly stating improved tumor control as a result). This reduces downstream usefulness because reviewers typically need an explicit efficacy outcome statement even if no numeric tumor-control endpoint is provided.

Controls/null results are incomplete: the report states that ICI-only treatment had limited activity in low-immunogenic settings (L37), but this control finding is omitted from output/quantitative_findings.json controls_or_null_results (only L36, L38, L39 are included). This is a main comparator caveat for interpreting sensitization claims.

Claim coverage imbalance: outputs emphasize mechanistic markers (immunopeptidome breadth, IFN score, PD-L1, CD8 density; L28–L33) and the retrospective survival association (L30), but underrepresent the stated combined-therapy efficacy interpretation (L46) and the practical takeaway that prospective randomized studies are required before protocol changes (L55–L56). Some caution is present in public_summary.json, but it is not consistently represented across the structured claim/quantitative layers.
value.summary: The JSON is largely faithful on the quantitative values reported (L28–L33) and correctly flags key human-study caveats (L49–L52). However, it fails the usefulness/coverage bar because it does not clearly encode the report’s primary efficacy conclusion—improved tumor control in mice with the combination (L46)—and it omits an important control/comparator statement about ICI-only having limited activity (L37). public_summary.json includes novelty phrasing not grounded in the report: “This is the first phase-curve study of TRAPPIST-1 b using JWST MIRI spectroscopy” is not stated anywhere in the provided report lines (no supporting line reference), so it is an ungrounded claim.

public_summary.json “what_is_new” uses ‘detection’ framing for epsilon=0.19 (“The detection of non-zero heat transport efficiency… provides evidence…”). The report’s calibration is that non-zero redistribution is favored (L28) with large uncertainties and weaker nightside constraints (L50); calling it a detection without uncertainty language is too strong.
